title: Human Body Systems
content:
# Human Body Systems

## Circulatory System

### Heart
- Four chambers: 2 Atria (upper), 2 Ventricles (lower)
- Weight: ~300 grams
- Beats: 72 times/minute (average)
- Pacemaker: SA Node (Sino-Atrial Node)

### Blood Circulation
- **Pulmonary**: Heart → Lungs → Heart
- **Systemic**: Heart → Body → Heart

### Blood Components
| Component | Function | % of Blood |
|-----------|----------|------------|
| Plasma | Transport medium | 55% |
| RBC | Oxygen transport | 40-45% |
| WBC | Fight infections | <1% |
| Platelets | Blood clotting | <1% |

### Blood Groups
| Group | Can Donate To | Can Receive From |
|-------|---------------|------------------|
| A | A, AB | A, O |
| B | B, AB | B, O |
| AB | AB only | A, B, AB, O (Universal Recipient) |
| O | A, B, AB, O (Universal Donor) | O only |

## Respiratory System

### Organs
Nose → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli

### Key Facts
- **Alveoli**: Gas exchange site (O₂ ↔ CO₂)
- **Breathing rate**: 12-20 breaths/minute
- **Lung capacity**: ~6 liters
- **Diaphragm**: Main breathing muscle

## Digestive System

### Digestive Path
Mouth → Esophagus → Stomach → Small Intestine → Large Intestine → Rectum

### Digestive Juices
| Juice | Source | Digests |
|-------|--------|----------|
| Saliva | Salivary glands | Starch |
| Gastric juice | Stomach | Proteins |
| Bile | Liver | Fats (emulsification) |
| Pancreatic juice | Pancreas | All nutrients |
| Intestinal juice | Small intestine | Final digestion |

### Key Organs
- **Liver**: Largest internal organ, produces bile
- **Small intestine**: Main absorption site (~6 meters)
- **Large intestine**: Water absorption (~1.5 meters)

## Nervous System

### Components
- **CNS**: Brain + Spinal Cord
- **PNS**: Nerves throughout body

### Brain Parts
| Part | Function |
|------|----------|
| Cerebrum | Thinking, memory, speech |
| Cerebellum | Balance, coordination |
| Medulla | Involuntary actions (breathing, heartbeat) |
| Hypothalamus | Temperature, hunger, thirst |

## Skeletal System

### Facts
- Total bones (adult): **206**
- Smallest bone: Stapes (ear)
- Largest bone: Femur (thigh)
- Only bone not connected: Hyoid (throat)

## Excretory System

### Kidneys
- Filter blood, produce urine
- Functional unit: Nephron (~1 million per kidney)
- Daily urine: 1-2 liters

title: Vitamins and Nutrition
content:
# Vitamins and Nutrition

## Fat-Soluble Vitamins (A, D, E, K)

| Vitamin | Chemical Name | Source | Deficiency Disease |
|---------|---------------|--------|--------------------|
| A | Retinol | Carrot, Milk, Liver | Night blindness, Xerophthalmia |
| D | Calciferol | Sunlight, Fish oil | Rickets (children), Osteomalacia (adults) |
| E | Tocopherol | Vegetable oils, Nuts | Sterility, Muscle weakness |
| K | Phylloquinone | Green vegetables | Delayed blood clotting |

## Water-Soluble Vitamins (B-complex, C)

| Vitamin | Chemical Name | Source | Deficiency Disease |
|---------|---------------|--------|--------------------|
| B1 | Thiamine | Cereals, Pulses | Beriberi |
| B2 | Riboflavin | Milk, Eggs | Cheilosis, Glossitis |
| B3 | Niacin | Meat, Groundnuts | Pellagra |
| B5 | Pantothenic acid | Widespread | Rare deficiency |
| B6 | Pyridoxine | Meat, Fish | Anemia, Dermatitis |
| B7 | Biotin | Eggs, Liver | Dermatitis |
| B9 | Folic acid | Green vegetables | Anemia, Neural tube defects |
| B12 | Cyanocobalamin | Meat, Fish, Dairy | Pernicious anemia |
| C | Ascorbic acid | Citrus fruits, Amla | Scurvy |

## Important Minerals

| Mineral | Function | Source | Deficiency |
|---------|----------|--------|------------|
| Calcium | Bones, teeth | Milk, Dairy | Osteoporosis |
| Iron | Hemoglobin | Spinach, Meat | Anemia |
| Iodine | Thyroid hormones | Iodized salt, Seafood | Goiter |
| Phosphorus | Bones, ATP | Meat, Fish | Weak bones |
| Sodium | Nerve function | Table salt | Cramps |
| Potassium | Heart function | Banana, Potato | Weakness |
| Zinc | Immunity | Meat, Nuts | Poor wound healing |

## Macronutrients

### Carbohydrates
- **Function**: Primary energy source
- **Types**: Simple (sugar), Complex (starch)
- **Energy**: 4 kcal/gram
- **Sources**: Rice, Wheat, Potato

### Proteins
- **Function**: Body building, repair
- **Energy**: 4 kcal/gram
- **Sources**: Pulses, Eggs, Meat, Milk
- **Building blocks**: Amino acids (20 types)

### Fats
- **Function**: Energy storage, insulation
- **Energy**: 9 kcal/gram
- **Types**: Saturated, Unsaturated
- **Sources**: Oils, Butter, Nuts

## Daily Requirements (Adult)
- Calories: 2000-2500 kcal
- Protein: 50-60 grams
- Carbohydrates: 250-300 grams
- Fat: 50-80 grams
- Water: 2-3 liters

title: Newton's Laws of Motion
content:
# Newton's Laws of Motion

## First Law (Law of Inertia)

### Statement
An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same velocity, unless acted upon by an external force.

### Inertia
- Property of matter to resist change
- Depends on mass
- More mass = More inertia

### Examples
- Passengers jerk forward when bus stops suddenly
- Dust comes off carpet when beaten
- Coin drops into glass when card is flicked

## Second Law (Law of Acceleration)

### Statement
Force = Mass × Acceleration
**F = ma**

### Units
| Quantity | SI Unit |
|----------|----------|
| Force | Newton (N) |
| Mass | Kilogram (kg) |
| Acceleration | m/s² |

### Key Points
- 1 Newton = Force needed to accelerate 1 kg by 1 m/s²
- Force and acceleration are in same direction
- More force = More acceleration (for same mass)

### Derived Formulas
- Weight = mg (where g = 9.8 m/s²)
- Momentum = mv
- Impulse = F × t = Change in momentum

## Third Law (Action-Reaction)

### Statement
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

### Key Points
- Action and reaction act on different bodies
- They are equal in magnitude, opposite in direction
- They occur simultaneously

### Examples
- Walking (push ground backward, move forward)
- Rocket propulsion
- Swimming
- Gun recoil

## Important Equations

### Equations of Motion
| Equation | Formula |
|----------|----------|
| First | v = u + at |
| Second | s = ut + ½at² |
| Third | v² = u² + 2as |

Where:
- u = Initial velocity
- v = Final velocity
- a = Acceleration
- t = Time
- s = Displacement

## Friction

### Types
| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| Static | Between stationary surfaces (highest) |
| Kinetic | Between moving surfaces |
| Rolling | During rolling motion (lowest) |

### Formula
Frictional Force = μ × Normal Force
(μ = coefficient of friction)

## Circular Motion

### Centripetal Force
- Directed towards center
- F = mv²/r

### Centrifugal Force
- Pseudo force (outward)
- Only in rotating reference frame

title: Periodic Table of Elements
content:
# Periodic Table of Elements

## History
- **Mendeleev's Periodic Law (1869)**: Properties are periodic functions of atomic mass
- **Modern Periodic Law**: Properties are periodic functions of atomic number

## Structure
- **Periods**: 7 horizontal rows
- **Groups**: 18 vertical columns
- **Total Elements**: 118 (as of 2024)

## Classification

### By Type
| Category | Examples | Position |
|----------|----------|----------|
| Metals | Iron, Copper, Gold | Left and center |
| Non-metals | Oxygen, Carbon, Nitrogen | Right side |
| Metalloids | Silicon, Germanium | Staircase line |
| Noble gases | Helium, Neon, Argon | Group 18 |

### By Block
| Block | Groups | Elements |
|-------|--------|----------|
| s-block | 1-2 | Alkali, Alkaline earth metals |
| p-block | 13-18 | Includes non-metals, metalloids |
| d-block | 3-12 | Transition metals |
| f-block | - | Lanthanides, Actinides |

## Important Elements

### First 20 Elements
| No. | Symbol | Name | Atomic Mass |
|-----|--------|------|-------------|
| 1 | H | Hydrogen | 1 |
| 2 | He | Helium | 4 |
| 6 | C | Carbon | 12 |
| 7 | N | Nitrogen | 14 |
| 8 | O | Oxygen | 16 |
| 11 | Na | Sodium | 23 |
| 12 | Mg | Magnesium | 24 |
| 13 | Al | Aluminum | 27 |
| 17 | Cl | Chlorine | 35.5 |
| 20 | Ca | Calcium | 40 |

### Important Metals
| Metal | Symbol | Property |
|-------|--------|----------|
| Iron | Fe | Most used metal |
| Copper | Cu | Good conductor |
| Gold | Au | Most malleable |
| Silver | Ag | Best conductor |
| Mercury | Hg | Liquid at room temp |
| Tungsten | W | Highest melting point |

## Periodic Trends

| Property | Along Period (→) | Down Group (↓) |
|----------|------------------|----------------|
| Atomic size | Decreases | Increases |
| Ionization energy | Increases | Decreases |
| Electronegativity | Increases | Decreases |
| Metallic character | Decreases | Increases |

## Valency
- Group 1: +1 (Na⁺, K⁺)
- Group 2: +2 (Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺)
- Group 17: -1 (Cl⁻, Br⁻)

## Important Compounds
| Common Name | Chemical Name | Formula |
|-------------|---------------|----------|
| Water | Hydrogen Oxide | H₂O |
| Table Salt | Sodium Chloride | NaCl |
| Limestone | Calcium Carbonate | CaCO₃ |
| Quick Lime | Calcium Oxide | CaO |
| Caustic Soda | Sodium Hydroxide | NaOH |

title: Acids, Bases and Salts
content:
# Acids, Bases and Salts

## Acids

### Properties
- Sour taste
- Turn blue litmus red
- pH < 7
- React with metals to produce H₂
- Conduct electricity (when dissolved)

### Common Acids
| Acid | Formula | Found In |
|------|---------|----------|
| Hydrochloric | HCl | Stomach, Cleaning |
| Sulfuric | H₂SO₄ | Batteries |
| Nitric | HNO₃ | Fertilizers |
| Acetic | CH₃COOH | Vinegar |
| Citric | C₆H₈O₇ | Citrus fruits |
| Carbonic | H₂CO₃ | Soda water |
| Lactic | C₃H₆O₃ | Curd, Sour milk |
| Formic | HCOOH | Ant sting |
| Oxalic | C₂H₂O₄ | Tomato |
| Tartaric | C₄H₆O₆ | Grapes, Tamarind |

## Bases

### Properties
- Bitter taste
- Soapy feel
- Turn red litmus blue
- pH > 7
- React with acids (neutralization)

### Common Bases
| Base | Formula | Use |
|------|---------|-----|
| Sodium hydroxide | NaOH | Soap making |
| Potassium hydroxide | KOH | Soft soap |
| Calcium hydroxide | Ca(OH)₂ | Whitewash |
| Ammonia | NH₃ | Fertilizers |
| Magnesium hydroxide | Mg(OH)₂ | Antacid |

## pH Scale

| pH | Nature | Examples |
|----|--------|----------|
| 0-3 | Strong acid | HCl, Battery acid |
| 4-6 | Weak acid | Vinegar, Lemon |
| 7 | Neutral | Pure water |
| 8-10 | Weak base | Baking soda, Soap |
| 11-14 | Strong base | NaOH, Bleach |

### pH of Common Substances
- Gastric juice: 1-2
- Lemon juice: 2
- Vinegar: 3
- Coffee: 5
- Milk: 6.5
- Blood: 7.4
- Seawater: 8
- Soap: 9-10

## Salts

### Formation
Acid + Base → Salt + Water
(Neutralization reaction)

### Types of Salts
| Type | Example |
|------|----------|
| Normal salt | NaCl |
| Acidic salt | NaHSO₄ |
| Basic salt | Mg(OH)Cl |
| Double salt | K₂SO₄.Al₂(SO₄)₃.24H₂O (Alum) |

### Important Salts
| Salt | Formula | Use |
|------|---------|-----|
| Common salt | NaCl | Cooking |
| Baking soda | NaHCO₃ | Baking, Antacid |
| Washing soda | Na₂CO₃.10H₂O | Cleaning |
| Plaster of Paris | CaSO₄.½H₂O | Casts, Molds |
| Bleaching powder | Ca(OCl)₂ | Disinfectant |
